review_title: A Golden Egg Company for Entry Level Career Workers
pros:
Apple is overall a great company to work for. I had an amazing time there with the staff, customers, and the innovative company culture. Working there is a pretty fun ride and the management staff is generally very supportive of new ideas and opportunities. 

Apple also tends to have a 'fast track career' culture, which allows for people with noticeably exceptional skills or particularly hard workers to quickly rise in the ranks or become managers in a lot of areas, so I believe that the company is very good for career growth. Especially for new college graduates and entry-level staff. 

Many other companies regularly scout Apple employees as a resource for their own companies, management staff later, hence the `Golden Egg` moniker. Once you`ve been hired by Apple and have stayed there for over a year or so, then you can basically write your own ticket in terms of future career paths later in most cases because ex-Apple employees are always in high demand.

The salary for the positions is also pretty good and competitive in the job market.
cons:
There aren`t really too many cons to working in this environment from my perspective, however, (depending on the area) I do feel that the majority of primary candidates for many of their roles would probably be people of a younger demographic who don`t necessarily have so many family responsibilities or children when starting out. 

Apple is very much an equal opportunity employer in most cases and they do have their quotas for SDG compliance, but I believe that the company still more geared towards younger, single, and more flexible employees in terms of upper management positions, higher salaries, and promotions. 

In a way, it kind of makes sense, because Apple is always looking for people with new, fresh ideas and a good level of communication skills/social interactions. On the other side though, depending on the area of employment, older staff or staff with more family obligations may find their options for promotion or getting a salary increase based on longer service years at the company a bit more competitive than in other places.

cons:
Some stores/managers are extremely toxic.
Most stores don't have an actually break room or place to get away to in order to reset or eat on lunches and if so those rooms can take over half your break to walk to and from (they do not account for this as farms when your break starts).  2 of the 3 stores I worked at only had the tiny corridor between the door in the back of the store to the tech computer room to use for a break. Sit on a stool that lines the super narrow corridor while your colleagues maneuver around you to work. 
The customers can be nice, but a lot can be downright toxic and vile. 
As a technician you are expected to meet, ask all the questions to try and understand what's going on with the customers device, explain the problem to them, provide options for solutions, carry out those solutions and make sure they are set to use their device again all within 10- 20 min MAX! Heck, software resets (which is a common solution) can take anywhere from 5 minutes to an hour depending on the device. You are expected to work at lightning speed without reprieve and it  WILL suck the life out of you no matter how hard you try to do a good job for both you're employer and customer. 
There are a lot of changes, always, but this can be a good thing just depending on how you look at it.

job_title: AppleCare Senior Technical Advisor in Cork
pros: Good benefits but nothing that most other tech company doesn’t provide.
cons:
It is only now a year later when I have time to think of an ideal review but I still can’t find the words to how awful and brutal AppleCare is to work for. 

They have their staff brainwashed into thinking it’s normal that every second of every trip to the toilet is measured. 

You have a certain average call handling time that you must keep under. But don’t be too good at your job - because if it’s too low then that’s not good either. (There’s also 13 more of these metrics).

You have set breaks and lunches. 2 breaks and 1 lunch. The break is 15 mins and you cannot be late back. You can barely butter a slice of toast or get a cup of tea. A manager once pointed out to me that “looking back we can see that you’re taking an extra 10 seconds on all of your breaks the last week. Can you explain yourself?!”

Getting time off is like getting blood from a stone. Extremely difficult. I requested some time off once as I had to look after elderly and very old grandfather and I was bombarded and harassed with questions. You’re also not allowed to be sick more than twice in the year. 

I could go on listing everything that’s wrong here and it’s complete slavery. If you love being handcuffed to your desk and tortured every single day, then be my guest and apply. In hindsight would rather go on welfare than go back there. 

I could go on all day talking about horror stories and Amazon warehouses do not have a patch on this. But I would beg anyone for their own sake not to join AppleCare. If you value any of your sanity do not do it. Avoid at all costs and don’t be fooled by the flashy Apple name or brand!

job_title: IOS App Reviewer in Sunnyvale, CA
pros: Great company to work for, with a solid culture and vision, great benefits and employee support tools and resources.
cons:
Mostly overly worked employees. The company has become stingy with bonuses and rewards over the years, especially for those working at entry level positions. Behind the curtain and the company’s positive message, there is a cut-throat business where numbers and micromanagement matter over the well being of its employees.

Career opportunities have just recently started to become more available, however moving within the company is exceptionally difficult unless personal contacts are reaching out to you. The overall feeling is that growth is not promoted or encouraged as much as within other companies of the same size. 

If working from home has taught us anything, is that management has been proven useless, with few exceptions. The traditional hierarchy of AR is mostly inefficient, with the head of it dodging hot issues within the department.
